#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Pick Music for a Funeral
#Text=Though a funeral is a time of mourning , it is also a time to commemorate and celebrate the life of someone who has passed .
#Text=As such , the ceremony should convey who the deceased was , what was important in their life , and how others felt about them .
#Text=A good way to do this is through the song choices .
#Text=Every piece should be carefully chosen to express their beliefs and personality .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Researching Your Options
#Text=Take the venue into account .
#Text=If the memorial service is going to take place at a funeral home , you will be able to play almost any music that you like .
#Text=However , if the service will be held at a religious establishment like a church , then you may be held to the traditions and restrictions of that religion .
#Text=Be sure to consult with a clergy member to discuss any possible rules in regards to music .
#Text=Even if you ca n't play particular songs during a service , you may be able to play them while people are entering/exiting .
#Text=Decide if you will use recorded or live music .
#Text=Though recorded music is both cheaper and easier to find , live musicians can add a more intimate touch to a service .
#Text=If the funeral is taking place in a religious organization , you may also be able to utilize whatever musicians participate in regular services .
#Text=For example , many churches employ choirs and guitarists .
#Text=If you are going through a funeral home , check with the service director for what music they have on hand .
#Text=Many funeral homes have a large collection of music from varying genres .
#Text=Ask a friend or family member to sing .
#Text=Though it can be difficult and emotional , asking a family member or close friend of the departed to sing can add a deeper sense of intimacy to a funeral .
#Text=However , be sure to double-check with whoever you ask , as this can be quite a sensitive undertaking .
#Text=You do n't want them to be unable to perform or feel overly pressured because you asked .
#Text=Try something like , “ Hey Sarah , I was wondering if you would want to sing at Mary 's service ?
#Text=I know this is a difficult time , so please do n't feel pressured to say yes .
#Text=I just know the two of you were close and she always appreciated your voice . ”
#Text=Gathering Selections
#Text=Look at the music the deceased enjoyed .
#Text=A funeral is both a memorial and a celebration of the life of someone who has passed .
#Text=As such , it 's important to choose music that reflects who they are .
#Text=For example , if they had a favorite song or artist , try considering these options first .
#Text=Also , if there is a particular song connected to an important event or memory of this person , it can be a heartfelt way to pay tribute to their life .
#Text=Talk to family , friends , and others close to the deceased .
#Text=Not only will these people have a good idea of what the departed listened to and enjoyed , they will also be able to contribute ideas .
#Text=For example , they can tell you about special songs that reflect moments of the deceased 's life .
#Text=Perhaps a song linked to a shared childhood memory , or a significant family moment .
#Text=Try approaching them in a private moment and saying , “ Hey , I 'm trying to put together some meaningful songs for Mary 's service .
#Text=Is there anything special you know she wanted or that you would like ? ”
#Text=Search funeral songs on the internet .
#Text=If you are still having trouble after speaking to family and friends , try searching online for typical funeral songs .
#Text=There are a multitude of sites that offer song ideas from every genre , like the Funeral Celebrants Association .
#Text=Try browsing through lists for things like “ the top 10 funeral songs , ” or “ common songs for funerals . ”
#Text=These lists should give you a good general idea , which you can then build from and tweak to meet your own needs .
#Text=Finalizing Your Decision
#Text=Create a possible setlist of songs .
#Text=Once you have a good idea of what kind of music you want , it 's important to decide what songs will be played when .
#Text=For example , when people are arriving and being seated , while people are waiting for the funeral to start , and between readings or eulogies .
#Text=During times of procession or waiting , playing some of the deceased 's favorite songs can be a good idea .
#Text=You can also try sticking to instrumentals between readings .
#Text=Ask other family members or close friends of the deceased for their opinion .
#Text=They can help you put together a list to try and narrow things down .
#Text=You can also ask the funeral home or a clergy member for what is typically played and when .
#Text=They should also give you a good idea of how many songs you need for the service .
#Text=Review every song choice .
#Text=Before you pick a song , make sure to thoroughly go over every piece of it .
#Text=For example , listen to it a few times and make sure the lyrics are appropriate in context .
#Text=Certain songs , even if a favorite of the deceased , are not acceptable for a funeral service .
#Text=Songs with copious swearing or dark lyrics are likely to make guests uncomfortable .
#Text=Some standard funeral songs with good lyrics are Louis Armstrong 's “ What a Wonderful World , ” or Michael Crawford 's “ One Eagle Wings . ”
#Text=Put everything together .
#Text=After you 've chosen your songs and decided on a setlist , try to get all of the music together .
#Text=If you are going to use music directly from the funeral home , make sure you pick up the CDs as soon as you can .
#Text=If you are using your own music , then burning a CD of your own , transferring songs to a USB drive , or putting songs into a playlist on a music player like iTunes is a good idea .
#Text=You do n't want to get to the service and realize you 've forgotten something .
#Text=Having everything altogether will also make playing the music much easier .
#Text=Video
